text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits IRM 1.14.3, Furniture and Equipment Standards.

On October 1, 2014, Real Estate and Facilities Management (REFM) merged with Physical Security and Emergency Preparedness (PSEP) to create Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). This IRM was updated to reﬂect current organizational titles, terminology, references and

As of January 1, 2017, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) instituted a requirement that the IRM address relevant internal controls. This will inform employees about the importance of and context for internal controls by describing the program objectives and officials charged with program management and oversight. Internal controls are the program’s policies and procedures which

a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated and key terms deﬁned. b. Program goals are established and performance is measured to assess the efficient effective mission and objective accomplishment. c. Program and resources are protected against waste, fraud, abuse, mismanagement misappropriation. d. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. e. Financial reporting is complete, current and accurate. f. Reliable information is obtained and used for decision making and quality assurance. The previous version of this IRM contained detailed speciﬁcations for modular and systems
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS This IRM supersedes IRM 1.14.3, dated April 15, 2003.
Facilities Management and Security Services
Facilities Management and Security Services

Equipment Standards

) The IRS National Workspace Standards (NWS) is a facilities planning and space allocation tool for all individual workspaces and support spaces in construction, renovation, and relocation projects for the IRS. It is intended use by IRS FMSS project managers, designers, and other stakeholders. (
) Purpose: The IRS furniture standards provide policy for selecting furniture equipment speciﬁcally designed for efficiency in a quality work detailed in the IRS NWS and IRS Office Design Handbook. (

) Compliance with these standards and application of the principles IRS NWS and IRS Office Design Handbook: a. emphasizes ergonomic ﬂexibility and supports automation. b. exhibits design ﬂexibility and effective use of space. c. provides privacy for taxpayer interviews. d. offers functional, efficient offices. e. promotes good employee morale. f. demonstrates better property use. g. improves accountability. (
) Audience: Facilities Management and Security Services (FMSS). (
) Policy Owner: Chief, FMSS. (
) Program Owner: Associate Director, Project Management. (
) Primary Stakeholders: This IRM is intended for use by FMSS Territory Managers (TM), project managers, designers, and Business Unit (BU). (

) The FMSS Project Management Policy office provides guidance in and use of furniture components, furniture systems, and non-ADP all of which meet IRS standards, including: a. Helping FMSS project managers develop speciﬁcations and select furniture systems that meet agency standards. b. Establishing procedures for developing new workspace furniture for the standards. c. Approving inclusion of new workspace furniture models in the (

) Internal Revenue Manual
Furniture and Equipment Standards

The IRS National Workspace Standards (NWS) is a facilities planning and space allocation tool for all individual workspaces and support spaces in new construction, renovation, and relocation projects for the IRS. It is intended for use by IRS FMSS project managers, designers, and other stakeholders.
Primary Stakeholders: This IRM is intended for use by FMSS Territory Managers (TM), project managers, designers, and Business Unit (BU).

Helping FMSS project managers develop speciﬁcations and select furniture systems that meet agency standards. Establishing procedures for developing new workspace furniture models for the standards. Approving inclusion of new workspace furniture models in the standards.
a. The
Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) Chapter
, Subpart
- Acquisition of Office Furniture and Office Machines;
CFR
- Use Standards;
CFR
- Space Programming, Layout, and Design. b. The Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR),
Chapter
, Part
- Required Sources of Supplies and Services.
Associate Director (AD), Project Management regularly monitors the effective- ness of the NWS Standards and provides guidance in the acquisition and use
Facilities of furniture components, furniture systems, and Non-IT equipment, to comply with IRS standards in all IRS offices as new furniture and equipment are procured. (

) AD, Real Property Management develops Asset Management Plans (AMP) each IRS non-campus office building. The AMP process integrates business requirements, real property information, strategic planning, human capital, technology to optimize the size and location of each IRS office Post of Duty (POD). Strategic planning requires evaluating the adequacy of space and consistent application of IRS NWS. (

) Each AD, FMSS Operations is responsible for overall furniture and activities within their geographical responsibility, assuring appropriate tion of all matters relating to the furniture and equipment program, including funding and implementing instructions and guidelines issued by the Chief, FMSS. (
) Each FMSS TM is responsible for administering the furniture and equipment planning and designing activities in the offices assigned to their geographical territory. (

) Program Goals: The Furniture and Equipment Standards provide a for allocating and designing office space for each organization within IRS in and uniform manner. By following the processes and procedures provided in this IRM, appropriate type and sized workspaces will be built for each IRS BU. (

) Program Reports: The NWS is the comprehensive manual developed and maintained by FMSS Project Management which explains, describes, and trates workspace and support space furnishings and equipment, workstation models, and how to allocate appropriate amounts of space for each BU function. The NWS is located on the FMSS Project Management Shar

oint site. The Project Management system called Space, Time and Resources (STAR) uses the information in the NWS to allocate space and estimate for rent and furnishing office and support space. The STAR project manage- ment system can be found on the STAR Shar
oint site. (

) Program Effectiveness: When space is acquired or realigned based on the Furniture and Equipment Standards it will house the BU in enough space to functional, and the furnishings and equipment will support the work being done. (
) Annual Review: The workspace standards are reviewed at least annually accuracy and continued applicability for each organization. (

Program Goals: The Furniture and Equipment Standards provide a foundation for allocating and designing office space for each organization within IRS in a uniform manner. By following the processes and procedures provided in this IRM, appropriate type and sized workspaces will be built for each IRS BU.
Annual Review: The workspace standards are reviewed at least annually for accuracy and continued applicability for each organization.

Furniture and Equipment Standards
) The increased mobility of IRS employees, initiated by the Telework Enhance- ment Act of

, created an opportunity to update the individual workspace standards and support space standards for non-campus IRS space. Furniture and equipment for office-based and mobile workers were updated to support the effects of modernization in terms of electronic communications such as fewer employees requiring assigned seating in the office and the reduction in the need to store paper (
) The furniture and equipment standards as detailed in the IRS NWS
The furniture and equipment standards as detailed in the IRS NWS incorporate space allocation and furniture standards with facility planning guidelines to
Facilities provide appropriate working environments for IRS employees while using space efficiently and reducing long term facility costs. (

) The two concepts that drive the overall design of an IRS facility are: a. The corporate model for support spaces. b. A boundary-less open office plan for General Office (GO) employees assigned to workstations and non-assigned (hoteling) employees. (

) The IRS NWS planning tool was designed to meet the following objectives: a. Provide appropriate working environments for IRS Services and ment organizations, Operations Support organizations, and other programs and groups within the IRS. b. Support changing work patterns and technological advances. c. Promote efficient use of space and reduce long-term facilities manage- ment costs in all IRS facilities. d. Explain the fundamental space allocation guidelines and planning concepts upon which the IRS’ Space Requirement Module (SRM) the STAR project management system tool is based. (

) Space is allocated to each employee based on a limited number of typical prints as appropriate to the function. The job series and pay plan are listed tables that are used to map the employee to one of the typical workspace types. The SRM in the STAR tool employs this process to help the PM space appropriately while planning for space projects. These standards be applied to the extent possible. (

) Workspace furniture standards provide employees with furniture that their job operations. These standards emphasize ergonomic ﬂexibility, use of space, a quality work environment, and cost efficiency. The standards are to be followed whenever there is a change in facilities which affects spaces or when any furniture acquisition occurs. (
) For GO employees, there are three default workstation footprints: a. W.
- for most General Schedule (GS) office-based employees b. O.
- for office-based management c. O.
- only for executive or senior level management (

) Exceptions to the three typical footprints are listed in the NWS and in the tool. These exceptions usually occur for speciality groups or for job types require additional security, privacy or have face-to-face contact with the (
) The furniture and equipment standards apply to all locations and all IRS groups including: a. National Headquarters b. Services and Enforcement c. Operations Support
provide appropriate working environments for IRS employees while using space efficiently and reducing long term facility costs.

Exceptions to the three typical footprints are listed in the NWS and in the SRM tool. These exceptions usually occur for speciality groups or for job types that require additional security, privacy or have face-to-face contact with the public.
Equipment Standards

) Purchase of newly manufactured systems furniture for an entire office can quite costly. Other, less costly, options should be thoroughly considered prior acquiring newly manufactured products. Those options include: a. cleaning, retroﬁt of existing product. b. excess product shown as available from other IRS projects. c. purchase of refurbished products using IRS’ Furniture Exchange (FEP) contract or from GSA Schedule providers. (

) New furniture acquisition is generally from two sources of supply, and commercial sources. For additional guidelines on acquisition of personal property, see the Personal Property Management Handbook and refer to eral Acquisition Regulations (FAR) Part
, Required Sources of Supplies Services. (

) Government sources include: a. sources within IRS, e.g. redistribution of existing or warehoused b. excessed property from government agencies. c. established government sources such as GSA and Federal Prison tries. (

) Commercial sources include: a. directed commercial sources from Federal Supply Schedules. b. National Industries for the Blind. c. National Industries for the Severely Handicapped, Inc. d. open market procurements, which are made through Invitations for (IFB), Requests for Proposals (RFP), and Requests for Quotations (RFQ). (
) All components of a workspace must meet the American National Standards Institution (ANSI) and Business and Industrial Furniture Manufacturers tion (BIFMA) standards. (

) The following factors should be considered in selecting procured furniture: a. Construction b. Conformance to speciﬁcations c. Conformance to required standards (ANSI and BIFMA) d. Maintenance - ease of cleaning and repair e. Appearance - compatibility and ﬂexibility to ﬁt into the existing office ronment f. Availability - vendor’s ability to meet delivery schedule and provide required components as speciﬁed g. Cost Note: The list of factors is listed in order of importance for most projects, but also be determined on a case by case basis. (
) The IRS often uses Blanket Purchase Agreements (BPA) to obtain quantity discounts for frequently purchased items. The contracts can be found on the FMSS Project Management Furniture Shar
oint.
Furniture and Equipment Standards
(09-27-2018) Furniture Selection Factors
The list of factors is listed in order of importance for most projects, but could also be determined on a case by case basis.
The IRS often uses Blanket Purchase Agreements (BPA) to obtain quantity discounts for frequently purchased items. The contracts can be found on the FMSS Project Management Furniture SharePoint.
Facilities (

) Wage & Investment Field Assistance requires that each newly implemented TAC should be brought to standard in terms of furniture and equipment as Assistance speciﬁed in the TAC Design Guide. (TAC) Furniture (
) Speciﬁcations for furniture and equipment are outlined in detail in the TAC Design Guide. (

) The systems furniture, freestanding furniture and seating are items to be purchased using the TAC Furniture Contract vendor. Instructions for the furniture and other equipment can be found on the FMSS Project ment Shar
oint. (

) The FMSS Mandatory Chair Contract must be used for replacement of ﬁve more chairs of the following types: Chair a. Task or operational chairs b. Executive task chairs c. Conference chairs d. Side chairs e. Reasonable Accommodation chairs (

) Exceptions to the mandatory chair contract include: a. Cafeteria or break room chairs b. TAC seating (task, reception and conference room) c. Specialty type training room chairs d. Guest chairs used in private offices Note: The instructions for using the Mandatory Chair Contract can be found on FMSS Project Management Shar
oint. (
) The BPA for ﬁle cabinets is available for purchasing to ﬁll ad-hoc or project needs. Instructions for using the File Cabinets BPA is found on the FMSS Contracts ect Management Shar
oint. (

) Generally, ﬁnishes of surfaces are chosen to provide a decreasing from ceiling to ﬂoor. Avoid a highly polished or reﬂective work surface, Finishes and cially in the area surrounding the computer screen(s). It is recommended the work surface be of a medium-value color to minimize eye fatigue. (

) It is advisable to use light-value, neutral colors for ﬁle and storage cabinets, portion of the acoustical partitions, and all other large or tall furniture nents because they provide a more spacious appearance as well as for term layout ﬂexibility. Low proﬁle components such as desks, credenzas, ﬁle cabinets, and machine stands may be a dark, medium or light neutral however, non-glare ﬁnishes will reduce lighting problems in an automated ronment. (
) Accent colors may be used in selecting chair upholstery, a portion of the acoustical partitions, paint, and other ﬁnishes for walls, and artwork. (

) With the exception of the TAC, furniture ﬁnishes are not speciﬁed in the NWS and may be selected for each project. Project Managers must follow guidelines offered in the Project Manager Desk Guide and Office Planning

b. TAC seating (task, reception and conference room) c. Specialty type training room chairs d. Guest chairs used in private offices Note: The instructions for using the Mandatory Chair Contract can be found on FMSS Project Management Shar
oint. (
) The BPA for ﬁle cabinets is available for purchasing to ﬁll ad-hoc or project needs. Instructions for using the File Cabinets BPA is found on the FMSS ect Management Shar
oint. (

) Generally, ﬁnishes of surfaces are chosen to provide a decreasing from ceiling to ﬂoor. Avoid a highly polished or reﬂective work surface, espe- and cially in the area surrounding the computer screen(s). It is recommended the work surface be of a medium-value color to minimize eye fatigue. (

) It is advisable to use light-value, neutral colors for ﬁle and storage cabinets, portion of the acoustical partitions, and all other large or tall furniture nents because they provide a more spacious appearance as well as for term layout ﬂexibility. Low proﬁle components such as desks, credenzas, ﬁle cabinets, and machine stands may be a dark, medium or light neutral however, non-glare ﬁnishes will reduce lighting problems in an automated ronment. (
) Accent colors may be used in selecting chair upholstery, a portion of the acoustical partitions, paint, and other ﬁnishes for walls, and artwork. (

) With the exception of the TAC, furniture ﬁnishes are not speciﬁed in the IRS NWS and may be selected for each project. Project Managers must follow guidelines offered in the Project Manager Desk Guide and Office Planning
Design (OPAD) training materials for guidance on selection of ﬁnishes and materials, as well as obtaining agreement from end-users on the palette.

It is the responsibility of the FMSS Project Manager to develop the color palette for a project using their expertise, or by contacting the IRS A&E staff for assistance, or in consultation with the design team provided by GSA/ Lessor. End-users should not be asked to develop the project’s color palette.
Lessor. End-users should not be asked to develop the project’s color (

) Artwork plays an important aesthetic role in office environments and public areas. Tastes vary in artwork, as a result, the space designer is involved in selection of art. For design continuity, the artwork should be integrated into overall office design. Various forms of artwork can be used effectively in pleting the color scheme and providing a visual break for occupants. (

) The New Deal program Art-in-Architecture (A-i-A) developed “percent for art” programs, a structure for funding public art still utilized today. This program gave one half of one percent of total Estimated Construction Costs (ECC) of government buildings to purchase contemporary American art for that structure. IRS aligns with this practice to develop a baseline estimate for construction projects, when budget allows. For smaller budget projects, consider using a standard $
per usable square foot if artwork is ate to the scope and when budget allows. (
) Interesting prints are available in many sizes, covering a wide variety of themes. Pictures of local sites may be especially appealing. (
) Textiles in the form of wall-hangings or acoustical tiles on the walls may be effective in some areas; however, choosing ﬁre-retardant, soil-resistant is important. (
) Other forms of artwork include murals, sculptures, photographs, and large ceramics. (

) Plants add variety and color to the open office. Artiﬁcial plants are generally most economical, considering the longer period they can be used. Artiﬁcial plants must have a ﬁre-retardant rating and be cleaned regularly. Other plants are: a. Physically separating two areas. b. Deﬁning areas in lieu of screens. c. Visually identifying an area with a landmark. (
) Employee orientation is required to achieve maximum, proper utilization of new furniture workspace or equipment. (

) Orientation should include, but not be limited to: a. Instruction on the proper positioning of the employee’s head, hands, body, and feet within the workspace for maximum ergonomic comfort. b. Instruction and demonstration on using all adjustable features of the workspace components. (
) Photographs and actual workspace models can be provided for employees see before installation when new furniture is to be introduced. Vendors are Internal Revenue Manual

Facilities often amenable to send products without obligation for a trial period. When acquiring furniture for testing or demonstration, each office should follow lines as set forth in IRM
, Personal Property Management. (

) Demonstration and test of equipment or other tangible items with a vendor must be prearranged through the Contracting Officer as well as the Property Officer. The Property Officer’s prior approval must be obtained so any property provided for demonstration or test is cleared to enter or exit building. (

) When equipment or tangible item(s) are to be left for demonstration or test, Contracting Officer will notify the Property Officer and give the vendor dates of the demonstration or test dates and when the equipment or item(s) is to be removed. (
) A post-occupancy evaluation must be conducted
days after installation any new workspace furniture. (
) Post-occupancy evaluations are conducted to assure: a. Proper use of the workspace. b. All adjustment mechanisms on components, i.e. chairs and tables, are accessible and work properly. (

) Furniture purchased from a new supply source should be evaluated after in- stallation based on the following criteria: a. Feedback from employees using the items. b. Repair and maintenance records (i.e., Employee Resource Center tickets). (

) The role of the FMSS Project Manager requires a greater sensitivity and awareness of requirements for persons with special needs. To provide an propriate work environment for those with special needs, it is often to modify existing furniture and equipment, including those areas accessible taxpayers. Such modiﬁcations are referred to as Reasonable (RA). (

) An employee who has a special need requiring an accommodation will the process outlined on the IRS Disability Office (I DO!) website. The IDO signs a Reasonable Accommodation Coordinator (RAC) to help facilitate the process. The RAC notiﬁes the FMSS TM of the need and discusses the frame for action. (

) Requests from the RAC office will identify the need to rearrange, retroﬁt, or realign furniture or installation of a product to accommodate the need. Project Managers will research alternatives and provide options to the RAC quickly as possible to ensure the needs are appropriately addressed. (
) A post-occupancy evaluation of any newly designed workspace or installed produce will be conducted
days after installation to ascertain if the adequately addressed the need.
